Baire category theorem

A function f∈C([0,1])f \in C\p{\br{0,1}}f∈C([0,1]) is called Hölder continuous of order δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 if there is a constant C>0C > 0C>0 such that ∣f(x)−f(y)∣≤C∣x−y∣δ\abs{f\p{x} - f\p{y}} \leq C\abs{x - y}^\delta∣f(x)−f(y)∣≤C∣x−y∣δ, x,y∈[0,1]x, y \in \br{0, 1}x,y∈[0,1]. Show that the Hölder continuous functions form a set of the first category (a meager set) in C([0,1])C\p{\br{0,1}}C([0,1]).
Solution.

We denote the space of Hölder continuous functions on [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1] of order δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 via HδH^\deltaHδ.

First, let us show that for any δ>0\delta > 0δ>0, HδH^\deltaHδ is nowhere dense. It suffices to show that for any f∈C([0,1])f \in C\p{\br{0,1}}f∈C([0,1]) and ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, there exists g∈C([0,1])∖Hδg \in C\p{\br{0,1}} \setminus H^\deltag∈C([0,1])∖Hδ such that ∥f−g∥L∞<ε\norm{f - g}_{L^\infty} < \epsilon∥f−g∥L∞​<ε. Indeed, this implies that any open neighborhood in HδH^\deltaHδ contains an element outside of HδH^\deltaHδ, i.e., HδH^\deltaHδ has empty interior.

Recall that piecewise linear continuous functions are dense in C([0,1])C\p{\br{0,1}}C([0,1]) (e.g., fff is uniformly continuous, so we can approximate fff uniformly with a piecewise linear function on a fine enough partition of [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1]). Thus, we may assume without loss of generality that fff is a piecewise linear function. In particular, fff is some linear function f(0)+mxf\p{0} + mxf(0)+mx on [0,η]\br{0, \eta}[0,η] for some η>0\eta > 0η>0.

Our prototype for functions in Hα∖HβH^\alpha \setminus H^\betaHα∖Hβ are xαx^\alphaxα where α<β\alpha < \betaα<β. Indeed, in this case, Jensen's inequality applied to the concave function t↦tβt \mapsto t^\betat↦tβ yields

∣xα−yα∣=∣∫01tαχ[x,y] dt∣≤∣(∫01tχ[x,y] dt)α∣=∣x−y∣α,\abs{x^\alpha - y^\alpha} = \abs{\int_0^1 t^\alpha\chi_{\br{x,y}} \,\diff{t}} \leq \abs{\p{\int_0^1 t\chi_{\br{x,y}} \,\diff{t}}^\alpha} = \abs{x - y}^\alpha,∣xα−yα∣=∣∣​∫01​tαχ[x,y]​dt∣∣​≤∣∣​(∫01​tχ[x,y]​dt)α∣∣​=∣x−y∣α,

but

∣xα−yα∣∣x−y∣β=∣xα−yα∣∣x−y∣α⋅1∣x−y∣β−α→∣x−y∣→0∞,\frac{\abs{x^\alpha - y^\alpha}}{\abs{x - y}^\beta} = \frac{\abs{x^\alpha - y^\alpha}}{\abs{x - y}^\alpha} \cdot \frac{1}{\abs{x - y}^{\beta-\alpha}} \xrightarrow{\abs{x-y} \to 0} \infty,∣x−y∣β∣xα−yα∣​=∣x−y∣α∣xα−yα∣​⋅∣x−y∣β−α1​∣x−y∣→0​∞,

since the first term is bounded. Thus, our goal is to approximate fff near 000 with xδ/2∉Hδx^{\delta/2} \notin H^\deltaxδ/2∈/Hδ. If a>0a > 0a>0, then

0≤xδ/2−x≤aδ/20 \leq x^{\delta/2} - x \leq a^{\delta/2}0≤xδ/2−x≤aδ/2

on [0,a]\br{0, a}[0,a], since x∈[0,1]x \in \br{0, 1}x∈[0,1], so xδ/2≥xx^{\delta/2} \geq xxδ/2≥x, and because xδ/2x^{\delta/2}xδ/2 is an increasing function. Let a∈[0,t]a \in \br{0, t}a∈[0,t] be small enough such that aδ/2<εa^{\delta/2} < \epsilonaδ/2<ε. Then define

h(x)={xδ/2if 0≤x≤a,aδ/2if a≤x≤aδ/2,xif aδ/2≤x≤t,h\p{x} = \begin{cases} x^{\delta/2} & \text{if } 0 \leq x \leq a, \\ a^{\delta/2} & \text{if } a \leq x \leq a^{\delta/2}, \\ x & \text{if } a^{\delta/2} \leq x \leq t, \end{cases}h(x)=⎩⎨⎧​xδ/2aδ/2x​if 0≤x≤a,if a≤x≤aδ/2,if aδ/2≤x≤t,​

which is a continuous by construction. Essentially, hhh is xδ/2x^{\delta/2}xδ/2 for a small amount of time before becoming xxx. We claim that

g(x)={f(0)+mh(x)if 0≤x≤t,f(x)if t≤x≤1.g\p{x} = \begin{cases} f\p{0} + mh\p{x} & \text{if } 0 \leq x \leq t, \\ f\p{x} & \text{if } t \leq x \leq 1. \end{cases}g(x)={f(0)+mh(x)f(x)​if 0≤x≤t,if t≤x≤1.​

has the desired properties. On [0,a]\br{0, a}[0,a], we get

∣f(x)−g(x)∣=∣(f(0)+mx)−(f(0)+mxδ/2)∣=m∣xδ/2−x∣≤mε.\abs{f\p{x} - g\p{x}} = \abs{\p{f\p{0} + mx} - \p{f\p{0} + mx^{\delta/2}}} = m\abs{x^{\delta/2} - x} \leq m\epsilon.∣f(x)−g(x)∣=∣∣​(f(0)+mx)−(f(0)+mxδ/2)∣∣​=m∣∣​xδ/2−x∣∣​≤mε.

On [a,aδ/2]\br{a, a^{\delta/2}}[a,aδ/2],

∣f(x)−g(x)∣=∣(f(0)+mx)−(f(0)+maδ/2)∣=m∣x−aδ/2∣≤m∣a−aδ/2∣<mε.\begin{aligned} \abs{f\p{x} - g\p{x}} = \abs{\p{f\p{0} + mx} - \p{f\p{0} + ma^{\delta/2}}} &= m\abs{x - a^{\delta/2}} \\ &\leq m\abs{a - a^{\delta/2}} \\ &< m\epsilon. \end{aligned}∣f(x)−g(x)∣=∣∣​(f(0)+mx)−(f(0)+maδ/2)∣∣​​=m∣∣​x−aδ/2∣∣​≤m∣∣​a−aδ/2∣∣​<mε.​

Finally, on [aδ/2,1]\br{a^{\delta/2}, 1}[aδ/2,1], g(x)=f(x)g\p{x} = f\p{x}g(x)=f(x) by construction, so ∥f−g∥L∞≤mε\norm{f - g}_{L^\infty} \leq m\epsilon∥f−g∥L∞​≤mε, which proves that HδH^\deltaHδ is nowhere dense.

Now, define

En,m={f∈C([0,1]) | ∣f(x)−f(y)∣≤n∣x−y∣1/m}E_{n,m} = \set{f \in C\p{\br{0,1}} \st \abs{f\p{x} - f\p{y}} \leq n\abs{x - y}^{1/m}}En,m​={f∈C([0,1])∣∣​∣f(x)−f(y)∣≤n∣x−y∣1/m}

so that

H1/m=⋃n=1∞En,m.H^{1/m} = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty E_{n,m}.H1/m=n=1⋃∞​En,m​.

Notice that En,mE_{n,m}En,m​ is closed in C([0,1])C\p{\br{0,1}}C([0,1]): if {fn}n⊆En,m\set{f_n}_n \subseteq E_{n,m}{fn​}n​⊆En,m​ is a sequence which converges uniformly to f∈C([0,1])f \in C\p{\br{0,1}}f∈C([0,1]), then ∣fk(x)−fk(y)∣≤n∣x−y∣1/m\abs{f_k\p{x} - f_k\p{y}} \leq n\abs{x - y}^{1/m}∣fk​(x)−fk​(y)∣≤n∣x−y∣1/m for all k≥1k \geq 1k≥1. Sending k→∞k \to \inftyk→∞, we easily see that f∈En,mf \in E_{n,m}f∈En,m​ as well. Finally, observe that if α≤β\alpha \leq \betaα≤β, then ∣x−y∣≤1  ⟹  ∣x−y∣α≤∣x−y∣β\abs{x - y} \leq 1 \implies \abs{x - y}^\alpha \leq \abs{x - y}^\beta∣x−y∣≤1⟹∣x−y∣α≤∣x−y∣β. Hence, Hα⊆HβH^\alpha \subseteq H^\betaHα⊆Hβ, which means the Hölder continuous functions are given by

⋃m=1nH1/m=⋃m=1n⋃n=1∞En,m,\bigcup_{m=1}^n H^{1/m} = \bigcup_{m=1}^n \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty E_{n,m},m=1⋃n​H1/m=m=1⋃n​n=1⋃∞​En,m​,

so it is a countable union of closed, nowhere dense sets, hence meager.
